{{Infobox animanga/Header | image = DrSlump1.jpg | caption = Cover of the first manga volume | ja_kanji = Dr.スランプ | ja_romaji = Dokutā Suranpu | genre = [[Comedy]], [[science fiction]]{{cite web |url= https://www.viz.com/dr-slump|title=The Official Website for Dr. Slump|publisher=Viz Media |accessdate=October 27, 2017}} }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = [[Akira Toriyama]] | publisher = [[Shueisha]] | publisher_en = {{English manga publisher|NA=[[Viz Media]]}} | demographic = ''[[Shōnen manga|Shōnen]]'' | magazine = [[Weekly Shōnen Jump]] | first = February 4, 1980 | last = September 10, 1984 | volumes = 18 | volume_list = List of Dr. Slump chapters }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | title = Dr. Slump - Arale-chan | director = Minoru Okazaki | producer = [[Tokizō Tsuchiya]] | writer = | music = [[Shunsuke Kikuchi]] | studio = [[Toei Animation]] | network = [[Fuji TV]] | first = April 8, 1981 | last = February 19, 1986 | episodes = 243 | episode_list = List of Dr. Slump Arale-chan episodes }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | title = Doctor Slump | director = Shigeyasu Yamauchi | producer = | writer = Satoru Nishizono (#1-28)
Not Credited (#29-74) | music = | studio = Toei Animation | network = Fuji TV | first = November 26, 1997 | last = September 22, 1999 | episodes = 74 | episode_list = List of Doctor Slump episodes }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Dr. Mashirito - Abale-chan | author = Akira Toriyama | publisher = Shueisha | publisher_en = | demographic = ''Shōnen'' | magazine = [[Monthly Shōnen Jump]] | published = April 2007 }} {{Infobox animanga/Other | title = Related media | content = * [[List of Dr. Slump films|List of ''Dr. Slump'' films]] }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''Dr. Slump'''''|Dr. スランプ|Dokutā Suranpu|lead=yes}} is a Japanese [[manga]] series written and illustrated by [[Akira Toriyama]]. It was serialized in [[Shueisha]]'s anthology magazine ''[[Weekly Shōnen Jump]]'' from 1980 to 1984, with the chapters collected into 18 ''[[tankōbon]]'' volumes. The series follows the humorous adventures of the little girl robot [[Arale Norimaki]], her creator [[Senbei Norimaki]], and the other residents of the bizarre Penguin Village. The manga was adapted into an [[anime]] television series by [[Toei Animation]] that ran on [[Fuji TV]] from 1981 to 1986 consisting of 243 episodes. A remake series was created thirteen years after the manga ended, consisting of 74 episodes that were broadcast from 1997 to 1999. The series has also spawned several novels, video games and [[List of Dr. Slump films|eleven animated films]]. ''Dr. Slump'' launched Toriyama's career. It was awarded the [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for ''[[shōnen manga|shōnen]]'' and ''[[shōjo manga|shōjo]]'' manga in 1981 and has sold over 35 million copies in Japan. The manga was released in North America by [[Viz Media]] from 2004 to 2009. [[Discotek Media]] released the first five films in North America in 2014. ==Plot== {{See also|List of Dr. Slump characters}} ''Dr. Slump'' is set in {{nihongo4|Penguin Village|ペンギン村|Pengin Mura}}, a place where humans co-exist with all sorts of [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] animals and other objects. In this village lives [[Senbei Norimaki]], an inventor. In the first chapter, he builds what he hopes will be the world's most perfect little girl robot, named [[Arale Norimaki]]. However, she turns out to be in severe need of eyeglasses. She is also very [[naïve]], and in later issues she has adventures such as bringing a huge bear home, having mistaken it for a pet. To Senbei's credit, she does have super-strength. In general, the manga focuses on Arale's misunderstandings of humanity and Senbei's inventions, rivalries, and romantic misadventures. In the middle of the series, a recurring villain named [[Dr. Mashirito]] appears as a rival to Senbei. ==Themes== ''Dr. Slump'' is filled with [[pun]]s and [[toilet humor]], and parodies of both Japanese and [[United States|American]] culture.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/house-of-1000-manga/2011-03-10|title=Jason Thompson's House of 1000 Manga - Dragon Ball|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=2011-03-10|accessdate=2012-11-18}} For example, one of the recurring characters is [[Suppaman]], a short, fat, pompous buffoon who changes into a [[Superman]]-like alter-ego by eating a sour-tasting ("suppai" in Japanese) [[umeboshi]]. Unlike Superman, Suppaman cannot fly, and instead pretends to fly by lying belly down on a skateboard and scooting through the streets. Also, one of the village's policemen wears a ''[[Star Wars]]''-style [[Stormtrooper (Star Wars)|stormtrooper]] helmet, just as in the American movies. Toriyama himself has been portrayed as a bird (the "tori" in his last name means "bird", hence the name of his production studio Bird Studio), although it has been suggested (by himself even) that he actually based the design of Senbei on himself. In addition, other real-life people make appearances as well, such as Toriyama's editor ([[Kazuhiko Torishima]]), assistants, wife, his colleague friends (such as [[Masakazu Katsura]]) and others.{{cite web|url=http://shonenjump.viz.com/node/178|title=EXCLUSIVE: Masakazu Katsura Spotlight|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|accessdate=2013-02-04}} ==Production== With Toriyama a newcomer to manga and his editor [[Kazuhiko Torishima]] still relatively new at his job as well, the two worked for 18 months with Torishima rejecting all the author's ideas until the first draft of ''Dr. Slump''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/olliebarder/2016/10/15/kazuhiko-torishima-on-shaping-the-success-of-dragon-ball-and-the-origins-of-dragon-quest/#1b1b1ac8d9ab|title=Kazuhiko Torishima On Shaping The Success Of 'Dragon Ball' And The Origins Of 'Dragon Quest'|publisher=[[Forbes]]|date=2016-10-15|accessdate=2016-10-22}} One of these rejected works, {{nihongo|''Ageha-chō Kansatsu Nikki''|アゲハ町観察日記}}, served as a basis for ''Dr. Slump''.{{Cite web |url=https://dragonball.news/news/20180202_wx.html |title=[鳥山明ほぼ全仕事] 平日更新24時間限定公開！ |work=Dragon Ball Official Site|publisher=[[Shueisha]] |language=Japanese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202032908/https://dragonball.news/news/20180202_wx.html |archive-date=2018-02-02 |dead-url=yes }} Toriyama drew several short [[omake]] included in the ''Dr. Slump'' ''tankōbon'' volumes that supposedly depict actual events on the production of the series, although, as they are often humorous, the level of truthfulness to them is uncertain. In one, he claimed that when he told Torishima that he wanted to make a manga about a doctor, the editor told him to add a robot. Toriyama originally wanted a very large robot, but as it would not fit in the panels, he instead made it small. When Torishima rejected that idea, he made the robot a girl, knowing Torishima would find her "cute".{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume=9 |year=2006 |origyear=1982 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-4215-0633-3 |page=118}} He also stated that Senbei was supposed to be the main character, but his editor told him to make it Arale instead, which Toriyama agrees turned out better. The act of having Senbei and [[Midori Yamabuki|Midori]] get married came from having nothing else to draw that week, and it happened quickly because he does not like romance. He went on to state that Torishima does enjoy romance, and that the relationships of Arale and [[Obotchaman]], [[Akane Kimidori|Akane]] and [[Tsukutsun Tsun|Tsukutsun]], and [[Taro Soramame|Taro]] and [[Tsururin Tsun|Tsururin]] were all Torishima's ideas.{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume= 16 |year=2008 |origyear=1984 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-4215-1060-6 |pages=34, 48, 130}} Toriyama did not expect ''Dr. Slump'' to last long, as even before it debuted Torishima was asking him what he would draw for his next series. However, it lasted for roughly five years. When Toriyama began ''Dr. Slump'', he worked at home, where he lived with his parents, and had one assistant who worked one day a week.{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume= 2 |year=2005 |origyear=1980 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-59116-951-2 |page=133}} Toriyama has said several times that he typically would not have any ideas for the story for that week's chapter, but would think up something as soon as Torishima called asking.{{cite journal |title=ドラゴンボール 冒険SPECIAL |journal=[[Weekly Shōnen Jump]] |publisher=[[Shueisha]] |date=1987-12-01| language=Japanese}} He thought up each week's story as he drew and sent the rough draft to Torishima at ''Weekly Shōnen Jump'' headquarters in [[Tokyo]] by air courier from [[Nagoya Airfield|Nagoya Airport]]. After getting the approval of his editor, he began by drawing the lines that stick out of the frames, then the frames themselves, before using a g-pen to draw clear crisp lines at roughly one page an hour. After he had around eight pages finished, his assistant {{nihongo4|Hisashi Tanaka|田中久志}} (also known as {{nihongo4|Hiswashi|ひすゎし}}) came over, although Toriyama stated he only allowed him to color. For color pages, Toriyama first drew them with permanent ink and used water-soluble color pens, before touching up with a wet brush.{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume= 3 |year=2005 |origyear=1980 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-59116-991-8 |pages=72, 146, 160}} Later in serialization (around volume 13, as stated in volume 18), {{nihongo4|Takashi Matsuyama|まつやまたかし}} became his assistant when Hiswashi started his own series,{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume=11 |year=2007 |origyear=1983 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-14215-0635-7 |page=172}} although Hiswashi occasionally still helped out, as did Toriyama's wife when they were close to a deadline.{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume= 13 |year=2007 |origyear=1984 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-4215-1057-6 |pages=5}} In 2016, Torishima said that although ''Dr. Slump'' was very successful, having debuted at number two in the magazine's reader rankings, Toriyama wanted to stop it after about six months. He explained that because it was a self-contained comedy each week, if something did not work, the author had to change everything. Torishima said that because it was a top-ranking series, would regularly sell a million copies, and had an anime about to begin, ''Jump'' and Shueisha would not allow it to end. However, Torishima claimed the magazine's chief editor told him that if they could come up with something more interesting and successful then they could. In order to have time to discuss new ideas they had to adjust the weekly schedule, finishing a ''Dr. Slump'' chapter in five days instead of seven. Toriyama stated that one of the conditions he agreed to that allowed him to end the popular ''Dr. Slump'', was that he start his next series relatively soon after. He began ''[[Dragon Ball]]'' roughly three months later.{{cite book |title=DRAGON　BALL 超全集 4: 超事典|year=2013|language=Japanese|publisher=Shueisha|pages=346–349|isbn=978-4-08-782499-5}} In his own words, Toriyama described the scenery of ''Dr. Slump'' as having an "American West Coast" feel.{{cite book |title=DRAGON　BALL　大全集 4: WORLD　GUIDE |year=1995 |language=Japanese |publisher=Shueisha|pages=164–169 |isbn=4-08-782754-2}} Torishima recalled that when he asked Toriyama why he drew relatively sparse backgrounds, his reply was simply that it was easier that way.{{cite journal |title=Shenlong Times 1 |work=DRAGON BALL 大全集 1: COMPLETE ILLUSTRATIONS |publisher=Shueisha |year=1995| language=Japanese}} However, Toriyama has stated that he was particular about the art, working more hours on it than he would later on ''Dragon Ball''.{{cite book |title=DRAGON BALL 超画集|language=Japanese|publisher=Shueisha |pages=224–225|year=2013|isbn=978-4-08-782520-6}} In an actual chapter of ''Dr. Slump'', where Toriyama and Matsuyama appear, it was revealed that Matsuyama draws most of the backgrounds and houses.{{cite book |last=Toriyama |first=Akira |title=Dr. Slump |volume= 16 |year=2008 |origyear=1984 |publisher=Viz Media |isbn=978-1-4215-1060-6 |pages=11}} Toriyama often used colored paper, a technique fairly common in design, but less-so in manga. He stated that the tournament-type events, such as the Penguin Village Grand Prix and the [[kick the can]] contest, were popular with readers and inspired the Tenkaichi Budōkai in ''Dragon Ball''.{{cite book |title=DRAGON　BALL　大全集 2: STORY　GUIDE |year=1995 |language=Japanese |publisher=Shueisha|pages=261–265 |isbn=4-08-782752-6}} Torishima described the ''Dr. Slump'' anime as unsuccessful in his opinion because it did not loyally follow the manga. He said this was because it was the first time the ''Weekly Shōnen Jump'' team had to manage an anime based on one of their manga and its creative process, explaining that, if something went wrong, it was too late to change because it was already animated. ==Media== ===Manga=== {{Main article|List of Dr. Slump chapters}} [[Akira Toriyama]]'s ''Dr. Slump'' was originally serialized in ''[[Weekly Shōnen Jump]]'' from issue No. 5/6 on February 4, 1980 to No. 39 on September 10, 1984.{{cite web |url=http://mediaarts-db.jp/mg/magazines/322763 |title=週刊少年ジャンプ　1980/02/04・2/11合併　表示号数5・6 |website=Media Arts Database |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=February 19, 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://mediaarts-db.jp/mg/magazines/322528 |title=週刊少年ジャンプ　1984/09/10　表示号数39 |website=Media Arts Database |publisher=Agency for Cultural Affairs |language=Japanese |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} Its 236 individual chapters were collected into 18 ''[[tankōbon]]'' volumes under the ''Jump Comics'' imprint.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/zen_list.cgi?siries_isbn=X-08-851181-6&siries_kanren_isbn=&mode=2|title=Dr. スランプ 単行本|publisher=Shueisha|accessdate=2012-11-11|language=Japanese}} It was reassembled as a 9-volume [[Tankōbon#Aizōban|''aizōban'']] edition in 1990, a 9-volume [[Tankōbon#Bunkoban|''bunkoban'']] edition in 1995,{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/zen_list.cgi?siries_isbn=X-08-617051-5&siries_kanren_isbn=&mode=2|title=Dr. スランプ 文庫版|publisher=Shueisha|accessdate=2012-11-11 |language=Japanese}} and a 15-volume [[Tankōbon#Kanzenban|''kanzenban'']] edition in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/zen_list.cgi?siries_isbn=X-08-874174-9&siries_kanren_isbn=&mode=2|title=Dr. スランプ 完全版|publisher=Shueisha|accessdate=2012-11-11|language=Japanese}} [[Viz Media]] licensed the series for North America in 2004,{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-12-16/viz-officially-announces-dr-slump-and-legendz|title=Viz Officially Announces Dr. Slump and Legendz|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2004-12-16|accessdate=2013-04-14}} and published the first volume on March 3, 2005{{cite web | url=http://www.viz.com/manga/print/dr-slump-volume-1/5138 | title=Dr. Slump, Volume 1 | publisher=Viz Media | accessdate=2013-11-09}} with translation done by [[Alexander O. Smith]] and some [[censorship]]. All 18 original volumes have been released in North America as of May 5, 2009.{{cite web | url=http://www.viz.com/manga/print/dr-slump-volume-18/7347 | title=Dr. Slump, Volume 18 | publisher=Viz Media | accessdate=2013-11-09}} After ''Dr. Slump'' ended in 1984, its characters returned for an extended cameo in Toriyama's next series ''[[Dragon Ball]]'', in which Arale and [[Goku|Son Goku]] briefly team up to defeat General Blue during the [[List of Dragon Ball characters#Red Ribbon Army|Red Ribbon Army]] storyline. A ''Dr. Slump'' follow-up manga was written by [[Takao Koyama]] and illustrated by Katsuyoshi Nakatsuru, with supervision by Toriyama. It was serialized in ''[[V Jump]]'' from February 21, 1993 to September 1996 under the title {{nihongo4|''The Brief Return of Dr. Slump''|ちょっとだけかえってきたDr.スランプ|Chotto Dake Kaettekita Dokutā Suranpu}}. It was collected into four ''tankōbon'' volumes.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4088060032|title=ちょっとだけかえってきたDr.スランプ 1|language=Japanese|work=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.jp]]|accessdate=2013-08-10}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4088060113|title=ちょっとだけかえってきたDr.スランプ 4|language=Japanese|work=Amazon.co.jp|accessdate=2013-08-10}} To promote the release of the first ''Dr. Slump - Arale-chan'' anime DVD box set, Akira Toriyama illustrated a special one-shot colored spin-off manga titled {{nihongo4|''Dr. Mashirito - Abale-chan''|Dr.MASHIRITO ABALEちゃん}} published in the April 2007 issue of ''[[Monthly Shōnen Jump]]''. The story centers around an evil counterpart of Arale created by Dr. Mashirito Jr., named Abale. ===Anime=== {{Main Article|List of Dr. Slump Arale-chan episodes|List of Doctor Slump episodes}} The ''Dr. Slump'' manga was adapted into two separate anime television series by [[Toei Animation]], both of which aired on [[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]]. The first, {{nihongo4|''Dr. Slump - Arale-chan''|Dr.スランプ アラレちゃん}}, ran from April 8, 1981 to February 19, 1986 and spanned 243 episodes.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_arale.php|title=DR. SLUMP -ARALE- (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|accessdate=2012-11-11| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150722045110/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_arale.php| archivedate = 2015-07-22}} The second anime, simply titled {{nihongo4|''Doctor Slump''|ドクタースランプ}}, ran from November 26, 1997 to September 22, 1999 and lasted seventy-four episodes.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump.php|title=DR. SLUMP (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2012-11-11| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726234246/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} The first anime was released on home video for the first time in 2007, remastered, in two 22-disc DVD sets; {{nihongo4|''Slump the Box N'Cha''|SLUMP THE BOX んちゃ}} on March 23, which contains the first 120 episodes, and {{nihongo4|''Slump the Box Hoyoyo''|SLUMP THE BOX ほよよ}} on September 14, which contains the remainder.{{cite web |title=Dr.スランプ アラレちゃん DVD-BOX SLUMP THE BOX んちゃ編 |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000IU38II |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2013-08-11}}{{cite web |title=Dr.スランプ アラレちゃん DVD-BOX SLAMP THE BOX ほよよ編 |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000IU38IS |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2013-08-11}} Likewise, the second series was released the following year as ''Slump the Box 90's'' on March 21.{{cite web |title=ドクタースランプ DVD-BOX SLUMP THE BOX 90’S |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000WE66B6 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2013-08-11}} The first anime was then released in twenty 2-disc sets (the last was 3-disc) of roughly twelve episodes each, titled ''Slump the Collection''; the first three sets on October 9, 2008, the next five on November 28, the next six on December 21, and the last six on January 30, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/tv/arale/|title=Dr.スランプDVD "SLUMP THE COLLECTION"|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2013-08-11}} The first episode of the original anime was adapted into English by [[Harmony Gold USA]] in 1984, but the pilot was never picked up.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-x-button/2008-08-20|title=The X Button - Blown Away|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2008-08-20|accessdate=2013-05-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-mike-toole-show/2011-05-08|title=The Mike Tool Show - The Spirit of '81|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2011-05-08|accessdate=2013-05-25}} ===Films=== {{Main article|List of Dr. Slump films}} Toei has also created eleven animated films based on ''Dr. Slump'', beginning with ''Hello! Wonder Island'' on July 18, 1981.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/drslump_1_hello_wonder_land.php|title=DR. SLUMP 1 Hello! Wonder Land (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726231110/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/drslump_1_hello_wonder_land.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} They continued to produce one film a year until 1985; ''"Hoyoyo!" Space Adventure'' on July 10, 1982,{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_2.php|title=DR. SLUMP 2 (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726233115/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_2.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: Hoyoyo! The Great Race Around the World'' on March 13, 1983,{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_3_the_great_race_arou.php|title=DR. SLUMP 3 The Great Race Around the World (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726202114/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_3_the_great_race_arou.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: Hoyoyo! The Secret of Nanaba Castle'' on December 22, 1984,{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_4_the_secret_of_the_n.php|title=DR. SLUMP 4 The secret of the Nanaba Castle (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726232057/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_4_the_secret_of_the_n.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} and ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: Hoyoyo! The City of Dreams, Mechapolis'' on July 13, 1985.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_5_the_city_of_dream_m.php|title=DR. SLUMP 5 The City of Dream, Mechapolis (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726214638/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_5_the_city_of_dream_m.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} In 1993, ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: N-cha! Clear Skies Over Penguin Village'' and ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: N-cha! From Penguin Village with Love'' were released on March 6 and July 10 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_6_sunny_penguin_villa.php|title=DR. SLUMP 6 Sunny Penguin Village (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726203441/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_6_sunny_penguin_villa.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}}{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_7_with_love_from_peng.php|title=DR. SLUMP 7 with Love from Penguin Village (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726234051/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_7_with_love_from_peng.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} In 1994, ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: Hoyoyo!! Follow the Rescued Shark...'' and ''Dr. Slump and Arale-chan: N-cha!! Excited Heart of Summer Vacation'' were released on March 12 and July 9 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_8_trip_with_the_shark.php|title=DR. SLUMP 8 Trip with the Shark (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726230750/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_8_trip_with_the_shark.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}}{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_9_summer_vacation.php|title=DR. SLUMP 9 Summer Vacation (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726210721/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_9_summer_vacation.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} On March 6, 1999, ''Arale's Surprise Burn'' was produced.{{cite web|url=http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_arales_surprising_bur.php|title=DR. SLUMP ARALE'S SURPRISING BURN! (TOEI ANIMATION FILM LIST)|publisher=Toei Animation|accessdate=2016-12-24| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150726215656/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_arales_surprising_bur.php| archivedate = 2015-07-26}} Toriyama's 2007 one-shot was adapted into a five-minute short titled ''Dr. Slump: Dr. Mashirito and Abale-chan'' that was shown alongside the theatrically released ''[[One Piece Movie: The Desert Princess and the Pirates: Adventures in Alabasta]]''. In 2008, all eleven films were released in a remastered DVD box set titled ''Slump the Box Movies'' on September 21.{{cite web |title=Dr.スランプ劇場版DVD-BOX SLUMP THE BOX MOVIES |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0017W6AN6 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2013-08-11}} On June 12, 2013, [[Discotek Media]] announced they acquired the first five ''Dr. Slump'' films for release in North America. They released all five in a two-disc DVD box set in Japanese with English subtitles on July 29, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-06-12/discotek-media-adds-1st-5-dr-slump-anime-films|title=Discotek Media Adds 1st 5 Dr. Slump Anime Films|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2013-06-12|accessdate=2013-06-12}} ===Video games=== A series of three ''Dr. Slump - Arale-chan'' [[video games]] called {{nihongo4|''Hoyoyo Bomber''|ホヨヨボンバー}}, {{nihongo4|''Gatchan! Kazi Kazi''|巻 ガッちゃん! ガジガジ}} and {{nihongo4|''Ncha! Bycha''|んちゃ! バイちゃ}}, by Animest was released as [[Game & Watch]] clones in 1982. A ''Dr. Slump'' video game was released in 1983 for the [[Arcadia 2001]]. {{nihongo4|''Dr. Slump Bubble Blitz''|Dr.スランプ バブル大作戦}} was released for the [[NEC PC-6001]] in 1984 by [[Enix]]. An action game, simply titled {{nihongo4|''Dr. Slump''|ドクタースランプ}}, for the [[PlayStation]] based on the second television series was released on March 18, 1999 by [[Bandai]].{{cite web |title=Dr.スランプ |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B00005OVJD |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2013-08-11}} {{nihongo4|''Dr. Slump: Arale-Chan''|Dr.スランプ アラレちゃん}} was released on October 30, 2008 for the [[Nintendo DS]].{{cite web |title=Dr. Slump & Arale-Chan |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B001E17H1E |work=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=2013-08-11}} Arale appears in the 1988 [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Famicom]] game ''[[Famicom Jump: Hero Retsuden]]''. In the [[Nintendo DS]] game ''[[Jump Super Stars]]'', Arale and Dr. Mashirito are [[player character]]s, while Senbei appears as a support character. They both return in the sequel, ''[[Jump Ultimate Stars]]'' while Senbei, Midori, Gatchan, Obotchaman and Unchi-kun are support characters. Arale appears as a playable character in ''[[J-Stars Victory VS]]''.{{cite web|title=Haikyu, Dr. Slump, Bobobo-bo Join J-Stars Victory Vs. Game |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-02-12/haikyu-dr-slump-bobobo-bo-join-j-stars-victory-vs-game |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2014-02-12 |accessdate=2014-02-12}} Arale appears in several ''Dragon Ball'' video games as well. She and several other ''Dr. Slump'' characters appear in ''[[List of Dragon Ball video games#Dragon Ball: Daima.C5.8D Fukkatsu|Dragon Ball: Daimaō Fukkatsu]]'', she alone is a hidden battle in ''Dragon Ball 3: Goku Den'', and she and Senbei briefly appear in ''Dragon Ball Z: Super Goku Den — Totsugeki-Hen''. Arale is a playable character, and Penguin Village is a playable map, in ''[[Dragon Ball Z: Budokai Tenkaichi 3|Dragon Ball Z: Sparking! Meteor]]'' for the [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Wii]]. In the PS2 game ''[[Super Dragon Ball Z]]'', Suppaman appears in the background of the city level; after breaking the porta-potty, Suppaman will roll off on his skateboard. Finally, Arale can be unlocked as a playable character in ''[[Dragon Ball: Revenge of King Piccolo|Dragon Ball: World's Greatest Adventure]]'' for the Wii, ''[[Dragon Ball: Origins 2|Dragon Ball DS 2: Charge! Red Ribbon Army]]'' for the DS, and ''[[Dragon Ball Fusions]]'' for the [[Nintendo 3DS]].{{cite news|title="Dragon Ball Fusions" Game Adds Arale from "Dr. Slump" for More Fusing Fun|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/06/23/dragon-ball-fusions-game-adds-arale-from-dr-slump-for-more-fusing-fun|work=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=2016-06-23|accessdate=2016-12-24}} ===Other media=== There have been several [[light novel]]s based on ''Dr. Slump''. The first two, {{nihongo4|''Novel!? Dr. Slump''|小説!? Dr.スランプ}} released in July 1981 and {{nihongo4|''Novel!? Dr. Slump Strikes Back''|小説!? Dr.スランプの逆襲}} released in April 1982, were written by [[Masaki Tsuji]], who also wrote for the anime adaptation.{{cite web |title=小説DRスランプ |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4086104326 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{cite web |title=小説!?Dr.スランプの逆襲 |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4086104881 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-24}} A novel written by [[Shun'ichi Yukimuro]] and based on the second movie was released on July 15, 1982.{{cite web |title=Dr.スランプ映画編 |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4086105047 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-24}} {{nihongo4|''The Sun fell in Penguin Village''|ペンギン村に陽は落ちて}} and {{nihongo4|''Ghostbusters''|ゴーストバスターズ}}, released on October 1989 and June 27, 1997 respectively, are original works written by [[Genichiro Takahashi]], but draw from the world of ''Dr. Slump''.{{cite web |script-title=ja:ペンギン村に陽は落ちて |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4087727149 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{cite web |script-title=ja:ゴ-ストバスタ-ズ　冒険小説 |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4062072742 |language=Japanese |work=Amazon.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-24}} A [[Radio drama in Japan|radio drama]] adaptation was broadcast at around the same time the anime was airing. Arale was voiced by [[Yuko Hara]], keyboardist of the popular rock band [[Southern All Stars]]. In 2014, two commercials featuring ''Dr. Slump'' were created by Toei for [[Suzuki]]. The commercials advertise the car manufacturer's Kei [[SUV]] Hustler and include new acting from [[Mami Koyama]] as Arale and [[Kumiko Nishihara]] as Gatchan.{{cite news|title=Latest Suzuki Car CM Features Akira Toriyama's "Dr.Slump"|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/09/11/video-latest-suzuki-car-cm-features-akira-toriyamas-drslump|work=Crunchyroll|date=2014-09-11|accessdate=2015-03-08}}{{cite news|title=Suzuki Car Commercial With Akira Toriyama's "Dr.Slump" Updated for the Holidays|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/11/22/video-suzuki-car-commercial-with-akira-toriyamas-drslump-updated-for-the-holidays|work=Crunchyroll|date=2014-11-22|accessdate=2015-03-08}} In celebration of the anime adaptation's 35th anniversary, the ''Dr. Slump - Arale-chan N'Cha! Best'' album containing music from the series was released on June 1, 2016.{{cite news|title="Dr. Slump" Celebrates 35th Anniversary with "N'cha! Best" Music CD|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/05/11-1/dr-slump-celebrates-35th-anniversary-with-ncha-best-music-cd|work=Crunchyroll|date=2016-05-11|accessdate=2016-12-24}} ==Reception== As of 2008, the collected volumes of ''Dr. Slump'' had sold over 35 million copies in Japan alone.{{cite web |title=Top Manga Properties in 2008 - Rankings and Circulation Data|url=http://comipress.com/article/2008/12/31/3733|publisher=Comipress|date=2008-12-31|accessdate=2013-03-29}} Only a year after its debut, the series was awarded the 1981 [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for ''[[shōnen manga|shōnen]]'' and ''[[shōjo manga|shōjo]]'' manga.{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞: 歴代受賞者 |publisher=[[Shogakukan]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=2007-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094941/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} Viz Media's North American release of the first volume of ''Dr. Slump'' was nominated for the 2005 [[Quill Award]] in the Graphic Novel category.{{Cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20050718/38215-and-the-nominees-are.html|title=And the Nominees Are...|publisher=[[Publishers Weekly]]|date=2005-07-18|accessdate=2013-07-13}} The first anime adaptation of ''Dr. Slump'' was also popular, holding the coveted Saturday 6pm timeslot for five years. With a 36.9% average household rating, its December 16, 1981 episode is the third most watched anime since the television ratings group [[Video Research]] began keeping track on September 26, 1977.{{Cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2015-12-30/chibi-maruko-chan-sazae-san-dr-slump-top-list-of-most-viewed-anime-episodes/.97077|title=Chibi Maruko-chan, Sazae-san, Dr. Slump Top List of Most-Viewed Anime Episodes|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2015-12-30|accessdate=2016-12-03}} In 1982, it was voted the 13th Favorite Anime in Japanese magazine ''[[Animage]]''{{'}}s fourth annual [[Anime Grand Prix]].{{cite web| title = 第4回アニメグランプリ［1982年6月号］| language = Japanese| publisher = [[Animage]]| url = http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1982.html| accessdate = 2015-11-23| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140116212422/http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_1982.html| archivedate = 2014-01-16}} In 2001, ''Animage'' ranked it number 48 on its list of the Top 100 Anime.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2001-01-15/animage-top-100-anime-listing|title=Animage Top-100 Anime Listing|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2001-01-15|accessdate=2013-04-14}} [[TV Asahi]] released two Top 100 Anime lists in 2005, in the web poll ''Dr. Slump'' ranked number 34, while a nationwide poll of multiple age groups named it number 29.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-09-23/tv-asahi-top-100-anime|title=TV Asahi Top 100 Anime|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2005-09-23|accessdate=2013-04-14}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-09-23/tv-asahi-top-100-anime-part-2|title=TV Asahi Top 100 Anime Part 2|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2005-09-23|accessdate=2013-04-14}} The following year, a list created from polling 100 celebrities had it in the 25th position.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2006-10-13/japan%27s-favorite-tv-anime|title=Japan's Favorite TV Anime|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2006-10-13|accessdate=2013-04-14}} A running gag in ''Dr. Slump'' that utilizes feces has been reported as an inspiration for the [[Pile of Poo emoji]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3037803/the-oral-history-of-the-poop-emoji-or-how-google-brought-poop-to-america|title=The Oral History Of The Poop Emoji (Or, How Google Brought Poop To America)|publisher=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|last=Schwartzberg|first=Lauren|date=2014-11-18|accessdate=2018-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/24687/1/what-does-the-stinky-poop-emoji-really-mean|title=What does the stinky poop emoji really mean?|publisher=[[Dazed]]|last=Healy|first=Claire|date=2015-05-12|accessdate=2018-03-09}} [[Ian Jones-Quartey]], a former producer of the American animated series ''[[Steven Universe]]'' and creator of ''[[OK K.O.! Let's Be Heroes]]'', is a fan of ''Dragon Ball'' and ''Dr. Slump'', and uses Toriyama's vehicle designs as reference for his own. He also stated that "We're all big Toriyama fans on [''Steven Universe''], which kind of shows a bit."{{cite web|author=Ohanesian, Liz |url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/manga-series-dragon-ball-celebrates-30th-anniversary-5216554 |title=Manga Series Dragon Ball Celebrates 30th Anniversary |publisher=[[LA Weekly]] |date=November 17, 2014|accessdate=July 16, 2017}} Mike Toole of [[Anime News Network]] called ''Dr. Slump'' "the greatest manga of all time", filled with "parody, gags, and fart jokes that everyone from toddlers to grandparents can enjoy together".{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-mike-toole-show/2015-02-22/.85278|title=The Mike Toole Show - The Anime Alphabet|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2015-02-22|accessdate=2015-02-22}} [[Jason Thompson (writer)|Jason Thompson]] referred to ''Dr. Slump'' as the best series Toriyama has created, claiming it is better drawn and more creative than ''Dragon Ball''. He also reports that it is considered "the last non-manufactured hit" by many in the Japanese manga industry, particularity among ''Weekly Shōnen Jump'' titles.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/house-of-1000-manga/2013-10-17|title=Jason Thompson's House of 1000 Manga - Dr. Slump|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2013-10-17|accessdate=2013-10-19}} In their review, ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' stated "Toriyama has created his own demented sitcom, and his fantastic imagination and comic invention never let up", "The [English] translation is a bit flat, but the uncommonly good storytelling more than makes up for it."{{Cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-59116-950-5|title=Fiction Review: Dr. Slump, Vol. 1|publisher=Publishers Weekly|date=2005-05-09|accessdate=2013-07-13}} Eduardo M. Chavez of Mania Entertainment summarized ''Dr. Slump'' as a "quirky slap-stick comedy entirely based in fantasy."{{Cite web|url=http://www.mania.com/dr-slump-vol-05_article_82424.html|title=Dr. Slump Vol. #05|publisher=Mania.com|date=2005-04-02|accessdate=2013-07-13 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020065514/http://www.mania.com/dr-slump-vol-05_article_82424.html |archivedate=2013-10-20|df=}} He thinks that while Toriyama's usual art style uses "[[Super deformed|SD]]" characters, ''Dr. Slump'' also shows hints that he can draw realistic.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mania.com/dr-slump-vol-01_article_81985.html|title=Dr. Slump Vol. #01|publisher=Mania.com|date=2005-05-20|accessdate=2013-07-13|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020065516/http://www.mania.com/dr-slump-vol-01_article_81985.html |archivedate=2013-10-20|df=}} He noted that "little nuances", particularity puns, are lost in translation from Japanese to English and expressed disdain for Viz's censorship, saying it took away from the honesty of the series. Chavez feels that what the characters do never crosses the line into inappropriate; "The jokes might not be wholesome, but they are genuinely funny and harmless"; and went on to say that the series fills the void for "all ages manga" in bookstores and libraries. Reviewing the first five movies, Carl Kimlinger of Anime News Network summarized ''Dr. Slump'' as "random silly adventures [...] delivered with a lot of surreal nonsense humor, only the most basic sense of continuity, and not a whiff of substance or seriousness." He felt that much of the humor comes simply from the visuals; stating that the vintage hand-done art and animation provide a "warmth" and "raises Slump's visuals above" other anime. However, he called the background music "non-descript" and stated that the films are only for viewers who are familiar with the series, as they provide no [[Exposition (narrative)|exposition]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/dr-slump/the-movies-films-1-5/sub.dvd/.77308|title=Dr. Slump: The Movies [Films 1-5]|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2014-08-13|accessdate=2014-08-13}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Dr. Slump}} * {{official website|http://www.j-drslump.com/}} {{ja icon}} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722045110/http://corp.toei-anim.co.jp/english/film/dr_slump_arale.php |date=July 22, 2015 |title=''Dr. Slump - Arale-chan'' at Toei Animation }} * {{ann|manga|970}} {{Dr. Slump}} {{Dragon Ball}} {{Akira Toriyama}} {{Weekly Shōnen Jump - 1980-1989}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Shōjo}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Shōnen}} {{Bandai Namco franchises}} [[Category:Dr. Slump| ]] [[Category:1980 manga]] [[Category:1981 anime television series]] [[Category:1997 anime television series]] [[Category:2007 manga]] [[Category:Akira Toriyama]] [[Category:Comedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Comic science fiction]] [[Category:Fuji Television shows]] [[Category:Japanese films]] [[Category:Manga adapted into films]] [[Category:Science fiction anime and manga]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Shueisha manga]] [[Category:Shunsuke Kikuchi]] [[Category:Anime and manga featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Toei Animation television]] [[Category:Viz Media manga]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for shōnen manga]]

{{italic title}} '''''The Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance''''' ([[Facts On File]] Publishing {{ISBN|0-8160-4539-9}} and {{ISBN|1-4381-3017-1}}) by Sandra L. West and [[Aberjhani]], is a 2003 encyclopedia of the lives, events, and culture of the [[Harlem Renaissance]] of the 1920s to 1940s.<ref>Booklist, “Black History Spotlight: Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance,” 2004</ref> An [[ebook]] edition was published through Infobase Publishing in 2010.
==Additional authors==
In addition to the hundreds of articles written by West and Aberjhani, the Encyclopedia also includes an extended foreword by [[Clement Alexander Price]]. The founder and director of the Institute on [[Ethnicity]], [[Culture]], and the Modern Experience at [[Rutgers University]], Dr. Price in 2013 was appointed by [[Barack Obama]] to the presidential advisory council on [[historic preservation]]. <ref>White House Press Release: President Obama Announces More Key Administration Posts</ref> Other key contributors to the volume are: Iris Formey Dawson, Vaughnette Goode-Walker, [[Ja A. Jahannes]], Karen E. Johnson, and Mary C. Lewis.
==Reception==
Acknowledged as the first encyclopedic volume on the subject, ''Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance'' upon publication received generally favorable reviews. ''[[Essence Magazine]]''<ref>Evette Porter, “Book Gift Guide, Season’s Readings,” ''ESSENCE Magazine'' 34, no. 8,Dec 2003, p. 154</ref> featured the title in its [[Christmas]] and [[Kwanzaa]] gift-giving guide, the ''[[Times of Trenton]]''<ref>Times of Trenton</ref> described it as, "a fascinating guide to a colorful and culturally productive era in [[African-American history]]," and the ''[[Rudolph Fisher]] Newsletter'' called it, "an outstanding reference resource highly recommended for libraries of all sizes." In February 2006, ''[[Black Issues Book Review]]''<ref>Black Issues Book Review</ref> voted the encyclopedia one of its “essential titles for the home library.” In addition, both the American Reference Books Annual, and [[Libraries Unlimited]]’s Recommended Reference Books for Small and Medium-sized Libraries and Media Centers, list the Encyclopedia among its highly suggested titles.<ref>Bridget Slayden, "Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance," ''Library Media Connection'' April/May 2004</ref>
==Awards== Awards it has received include the Choice Academic Title [[Award]], the “Best History Book Award”, and the [http://www.njcenterforthebook.org/content/view/25/ "New Jersey Notable Book Award"] 1999-2005.<ref>A.C. Vara, "Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance,” [[Choice Magazine]] 41, no. 5 (January 2004)</ref>
==Impact on Field of Study== Since its initial hard copy release in paperback and hardback editions in 2003, Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance has prompted an increase in studies of the Jazz Age era <ref> Review of Harlem Renaissance: a Gale Critical Companion by Stephen C. Kenney with commentary on Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance included. Published by [[American Studies]] Resources Centre, Aldham Robarts Library, Liverpool John Moores University </ref>. Some of these studies have taken the form of novels and plays set in the era while others have resulted in new [[biographies]] of key players in the [[renaissance]]. In addition to being cited in numerous scholarly journals the [[encyclopedia]] has also become a resource for diverse authors who continue to expand and extend the [[field of study]]. The following is a partial list of titles that reference the volume:
*''African-American Holidays, Festivals, and Celebrations: The History, Customs, and Symbols Associated with Both Traditional and Contemporary Religious and Secular Events Observed by Americans of African Descent'' by Kathlyn Gay ([[Omnigraphics]] Publishing, 2007). *''[[African-American Literature]] Overview and Bibliography'' by Paul Q. Tilden (Nova Science [[Publishers]], 2003) *''Die Harlem Renaissance in Los Angeles 1920-1940'' by Jennifer Gladbach (GRIN Verlag Pub, Jan 16, 2017 *''Encyclopedia of the [[African Diaspora]]: Origins, Experiences, and Culture 3-volume set'' by Boyce Davies and Carole Elizabeth (ABC-CLIO Publishing, 2008) *''Ebony Rising: Short Fiction of the Greater [[Harlem]] Renaissance Era'' by Craig Gable (Indiana University Press, 2004) *''Greenwood Encyclopedia of African American Literature: U-Z, The'' by Hans A. Ostrom and J. David Macey ([[Greenwood Publishing]], 2005). *''Harlem Speaks: A Living History of the Harlem Renaissance'' by Cary D. Wintz ([[Sourcebooks MediaFusion]] Pub; with CD edition, 2006) *''Interdisciplinary Bibliographic Guide to Black Studies'' by GK Hall. (GK Hall Publisher, 2004). *''Music Musique: French and American Piano Composition in the [[Jazz Age]]''by Barbara Meister ([[Indiana University Press]], 2006) *''Political Aspects of “The [[New Negro]]”'' by Christoph Ellssel (GRIN Verlag Pub, 2008) *''Teaching the [[Harlem Renaissance]]: course design and classroom strategies'' by Michael Soto (Peter Lang Inc., International [[Academic]] Publishers; 2nd ed. edition 2008)
==Key [[100th Anniversary]] Source Document== Beginning with the 2011 [[essay]] titled “The Approaching 100th Anniversary of the Harlem Renaissance”<ref>The Approaching 100th Anniversary of the Harlem Renaissance by Aberjhani (AXS Entertainment Pub, 2011)</ref> the encyclopedia has been a key document in the call for official international commemorations of the Harlem Renaissance Centennial. == See also == *[[Aberjhani]] *[[Harlem Renaissance]] *[[W.E.B. Du Bois]] *[[Zora Neale Hurston]] *[[Langston Hughes]] *[[Wallace Thurman]] *[[Jean Toomer]]
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit-->
==External links== *[http://www.nathanielturner.com/weareadancingpeople.htm We Are a Dancing People by Sandra L. West]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=October 2016}} {{more footnotes|date=October 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = Global China Connection | image = | type = [[Non-profit organization]] | founded_date = 2008 | location = [[Washington D.C.]] | mission = Foster deep and trusting personal relationships among Chinese and non-Chinese university students | origins = | key_people = Jung Won Kim
(President)
Yihao Li (李一豪)
(Chairman of Board of Trustees) | area_served = Worldwide | homepage = {{URL|http://www.gccglobal.org}} | product = }} '''Global China Connection''' or GCC ([[Mandarin Chinese]]: 全球中国联接) is a student-run 501(c)(3) [[non-profit organization]] for university students and young professionals of all nationalities to engage China’s emergence in the world. GCC connects future leaders from all nations and assists them in developing the skills and friendships necessary to succeed both in China and internationally. GCC is today present in more than sixty top universities in North America, Asia, Europe, and Oceania, including [[Harvard University]], [[Yale University]], [[Princeton University]], [[University of Pennsylvania]], [[New York University]], [[Columbia University]], [[Cornell University]].http://www.gccglobal.org/chapters/ With its geographic reach, GCC connect thousands of students, recent-graduates, and professionals that are interested in China. Every year, GCC hosts hundreds of local, regional, national, and international events. GCC's main activities include hosting delegations of university students, China-focused social and professional events, and annual summits in [[China]] and the [[United States]]. The official languages of GCC are [[English language|English]] and [[Mandarin Chinese]]. Global China Connection was founded in 2008 at [[Columbia University]] with a motto "Building relationships that will change the world".http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-luce/global-china-connection-f_b_187855.html ==Organization== GCC's structure is divided into two components: GCC Central Management and Chapter Network. GCC Central Management manages overall communication and strategic activities, directs the network, and coordinates most of the organization's larger international events. The Chapter Network consists of individual GCC university chapters. Each chapter is governed by their own presidents and executive boards. At the top level, GCC is governed by a board of trustees (highly distinguished GCC members) and senior advisers (highly distinguished individuals outside of GCC). ==Events== GCC events connect companies, social organizations, and individuals through annual conferences as well as smaller scale forums. The organization hosts two major conferences each year, generally in New York City (spring) and Beijing (summer).http://edu.people.com.cn/GB/9769453.html Conferences contain discussion on subjects such as politics, economics, international relations, business, journalism, and culture related to China. Smaller conferences and events are also hosted by chapters within GCC.https://tuftsdaily.com/news/2014/04/22/speakers-discuss-china-u-s-relationship-during-annual-symposium/ Previous speakers at GCC conferences include: *[[Kevin Rudd]], former Prime Minister of [[Australia]] *[[Cui Tiankai]], Chinese Ambassador to the United States *[[Steve Forbes]], president and CEO, Forbes Inc. *[[Stephen S. Roach|Stephen Roach]], chairman of [[Morgan Stanley]] Asia and chief economist at [[Morgan Stanley]] *[[Orville Schell]], director of the Asia Society's Center on U.S. China-Relations *[[Susan Shirk]], former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State *[[Jin Zhijian]], Consul General of the Chinese Consulate in Christchurch *[[Kirsten Gillibrand]], U.S. Senator from New York *[[Joseph Stiglitz]], Nobel Prize-winning economist and Columbia University professor *[[Zhang Weiying]], Dean of [[Guanghua School of Management]] at [[Peking University]] *[[Bai Yansong]], [[CCTV]] anchor *[[Liu Xiao Ling Tong]] prominent actor in China best known for his role as the Monkey King in [[Journey to the West (1986 TV series)]]http://news.163.com/16/0324/11/BIU09QH000014JB6.html The smaller forums are based on subjects such as China's sustainable development/environmental protection challenges; the stimulus packages passed by China and the U.S.; the current state of the American media; U.S.-China relations; and China's developing capital markets. ==Delegations== GCC hosts and leads numerous student delegations in both the United States and China.http://news.sinovision.net/portal.php?mod=view&aid=109579 GCC generally collaborates with student association partners such as the Western Returned Scholars Association, the Students International Communication Association of Peking University (SICA), as well as student government groups, in managing these events. GCC delegations have visited companies such as [[J.P. Morgan Chase]], [[Ernst & Young]], [[Pricewaterhouse Coopers]], [[Microsoft]], [[The New York Times]], [[Baidu]], and [[Lenovo]]. ==Partners== Global China Connection's partners include: *[[Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business]] *Student Unions of Tsinghua University and Peking University (PKU) *Western Returned Scholars Association (欧美同学会) - *Center for China and Globalization (中国与全球化研究中心). *Ascend Leadership *Students’ International Communication Association at Peking University (SICA). GCC received SICA during their visits to New York in 2009 and 2010. SICA also helped host GCC's July 2010 conference at PKU. *Chinese Business Lawyers Association *Shanghai Youth League (上海市青年联合会) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.gccglobal.org Global China Connection Home] *[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-luce/global-china-connection-f_b_187855.html Global China Connection: From Columbia to Stanford and McGill] Huffington Post. April 20, 2009. Retrieved on April 20, 2009. *[http://columbiaspectator.com/2009/04/20/global-china-connection-host-conference Global China Connection to Host Conference] Columbia Spectator. April 21, 2009. Retrieved on April 21, 2009. *[http://www.columbiaspectator.com/2009/09/14/global-connection The global connection] The Columbia Spectator. September 14, 2009. Retrieved September 23, 2009. *[http://english.cctv.com/program/upclose/20090928/103915.shtml Up－Close 2009-09-06 Overseas students - 2] CCTV. September 6, 2009. Retrieved September 28, 2009. *[http://www.nj.com/news/local/index.ssf/2009/11/kinnelon_teen_creating_collegi.html Kinnelon teen helping create a collegiate network of China enthusiasts] NJ.com. November 2, 2009. Retrieved November 7, 2009. *[http://news.xinhuanet.com/video/2009-12/27/content_12707757.htm 美国大学生心中涌动"中国梦"] Xinhua. December 31, 2009. Retrieved August 31, 2010. *[http://www.columbiaspectator.com/2010/02/05/students-china-connect-columbia Students from China connect with Columbia] Columbia Spectator. February 5, 2010. Retrieved August 31, 2010. [[Category:International cultural organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests_for_approval/PrimeBOT_28|Task 28]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox company]] (+ genfixes)
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Goji | logo = | vector_logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | foundation = 2011 | location = Hemel Hempstead, United Kingdom | key_people = [[Tinchy Stryder]], [[Stanley Kalms, Baron Kalms|Lord Kalms]],{{clear}} Alison van Veggel | area_served = Global | industry = [[Music technology]], [[Sound recording and reproduction|Audio]],{{clear}} [[Consumer electronics]], [[Telecommunications equipment]] | products = [[Headphones]]
[[Audio equipment]]
[[Tablet computer]]/[[Mobile phone|Mobile]] [[iPad accessories|accessories]]
[[Laptop]]/[[Netbook]] [[Laptop skin|Cases]], [[Slipcase]]s | services = [[Music technology]], information and communications technology services, entertainment, [[retail]] | revenue = | operating_income = | owner = [[Dixons Carphone]], [[Tinchy Stryder]], [[Stanley Kalms, Baron Kalms|Lord Kalms]] | net_income = {{increase}} [[Pound sterling|£]]245.3 million ([[Second quarter of a calendar year#Subdivisions|Q2]] 2012) | num_employees = 3,300 | parent = | subsid = | homepage = {{official website|http://www.gojicollective.co.uk/entertainment/goji-tinchy-stryder-cloud-9}} }} '''Goji Electronics, Inc.''' is a producer of [[computer]], [[smartphone]], [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]] products and [[Audio equipment|equipment]] headquartered in [[Hemel Hempstead]], United Kingdom. The [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]] division of the company was founded by [[Grime (music)|grime]] artist and [[entrepreneur]] [[Tinchy Stryder]] and [[Dixons Retail|DSG International plc]] president [[Stanley Kalms, Baron Kalms|Lord Kalms]], and primarily produces products under the brand ''Goji Tinchy Stryder''. Since the inception of Goji, its products have been distributed by [[Dixons Carphone plc]] and its predecessor [[Dixons Retail|DSG International plc]]. The collaboration between Dixons and Kwasi Danquah III leads to an expansion of Goji Electronics into the [[headphones]] and [[audio equipment]] market. Stryder, Lord Kalms and [[Dixons Carphone plc]] all own shares in Goji. ==History== The company was founded in December 2011, and debuted its first product, [[consumer electronics]] accessories, in early 2012. Goji Electronics inception was made with [[Dixons Retail|DSG International plc]] granted exclusive rights to manufacture and develop Goji-branded products. With DSG International handling production of the products, Lord Kalms and Kwasi Danquah III are free to handle promoting the new line. Goji intends to primarily rely on [[celebrity endorsement]]s, particularly by popular professional [[Sportsperson|athletes]], [[popular music]]ians, to help market the line to a demographic of fashion-conscious young men and women. In June 2012, Goji Electronics expanded it products into the [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]], [[music technology]], [[travel]] – and with [[audio equipment]]. The Goji accessories for [[computer]]s and [[smartphone]]s were also expanded in June 2012, inline with the introduction of Danquah's headphones and [[audio equipment]] products. The percentage of stakes between the shareholders of Goji Electronics are not disclosed.{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/uk-rap-artist-tinchy-stryder-112900166.html |title=Goji Electronics: Range will incorporate headphones and travel speakers |author= |date=June 15, 2012 |work=[[Yahoo! Finance]] |accessdate=}} On August 10, 2012, ''Goji On Cloud 9'' [[audio equipment]] and ''Goji Tinchy Stryder'' [[headphones]] were distributed by over 600 [[retail]]ers in the United Kingdom, by [[DSG International plc]] subsidiaries in Europe, and globally by DSG International owned [[Pixmania]]. ==Products== The original product line of Goji were [[consumer electronics]] such as [[tablet computer]], [[netbook]] and [[smartphone]] accessories. The [[headphones]] and [[audio equipment]] product line of Goji were introduced as ''Goji Tinchy Stryder'' headphones and ''Goji On Cloud 9'' audio.{{cite web |url=http://mightygadget.co.uk/reviews/goji-tinchy-stryder-headphones-on-cloud-9-review/3461 |title=Goji Tinchy Stryder Headphones: On Cloud 9 Review |author= |date=August 10, 2012 |work=mightygadget |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813044440/http://mightygadget.co.uk/reviews/goji-tinchy-stryder-headphones-on-cloud-9-review/3461 |archivedate=2012-08-13 |df= }} Tinchy Stryder provides [[Creative director|creative direction]] on the development of the 'Goji Tinchy Stryder: On Cloud 9' product range, encompassing headphones, travel [[Loudspeaker|speakers]] and [[audio equipment]], and outlined in promotional materials that with current headphones, the look and pricing of headphones are not as flexible in value as people would like, and with Goji, its looks, audio quality, pricing and value flexibility will make Goji headphones and audio products a serious contender in the overall [[music technology]] market.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/tech/905433-headphones-head-to-head-top-headsets-for-the-best-beats |title=Headphones head-to-head - top headsets for the best beats |author= Andy Blackmore |date= |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |accessdate=}} Kwasi Danquah III added: "Goji Electronics has been the perfect partner for me to work with on this project – the team I'm working with are amazing and we clicked right from the start. I couldn't wait to get the products out there as I’m sure people are going to love the sound – which it was really important to me that we got right – and the design of the goods too".{{cite web |url=http://www.dixonsretail.com/dixons/en/mediacentre/mediapressreleases?id=539 |title=UK Rap Artist Tinchy Stryder Teams up with Goji to Develop New TechRange |author= |date=June 11, 2012 |work=[[Dixons Retail|DSG International]] |accessdate=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/uk-rap-artist-tinchy-stryder-teams-up-with-goji-to-develop-new-techrange-2012-06-15 |title=UK Rap Artist Tinchy Stryder Teams up with Goji to Develop New TechRange |author= |date=June 15, 2012 |work=[[Marketwire]] |accessdate=}} Inline with Goji headphones and audio equipment, it has also plans to license the Goji-brand and technology to other major [[information technology]] and [[Automotive industry|automotive]] manufacturers. Goji Electronics planned to begin offering [[personal computer]]s and [[tablet computer]] equipped with ''Goji On Cloud 9 Audio'' systems, which will feature advanced technological characteristics and software.{{cite web |url=http://www.pcworld.co.uk/gbuk/tinchy-stryder-headphones-237-commercial.html |title=Goji Tinchy Stryder Headphones: On Cloud 9, showcasing style and sound in a new collection of audio accessories |author= |date= |work= |accessdate=}} Following the expansion of accessories for [[computer]]s, [[tablet computer]]s, [[laptops]] and [[smartphone]]s in June 2012, Goji Electronics along with a future release of [[personal computer]]s and [[tablet computer]]s equipped with ''Goji On Cloud 9 Audio'' systems, also planned to begin releasing smartphones enabled with a ''Goji On Cloud 9 Audio'' technology in collaboration with major [[telecommunications equipment]] manufacturers. == See also == {{Portal|Companies}} * [[Music technology|Music Technology]] {{clear right}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|Goji Electronics}} *{{official website|http://www.currys.co.uk/gbuk/goji-collection-1215-commercial.html}} * [http://www.pcworld.co.uk/gbuk/tinchy-stryder-headphones-237-commercial.html The On Cloud 9 Collection] * [http://www.pcworld.co.uk/gbuk/tinchy-stryder-555-commercial.html About Goji Tinchy Stryder] {{DSGi}} {{Music technology}} {{Takeover Group}} [[Category:Companies based in Hemel Hempstead]] [[Category:Consumer electronics brands]] [[Category:Headphones]] [[Category:Dixons Carphone]] [[Category:Music technology]] [[Category:Electronics companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2011]]
